83377962.review:
[spoiler]Since I don't know English very well, I apologize for my mistakes.[/spoiler]

Most likely, my review will remain in the shadows, and hardly anyone will reach the end of my review, I still want to share with you my feelings and the seasoned spirit of adventure. It all started many years ago, when I got acquainted with one of the most wonderful, warm, and memorable games in my life - Terraria. When pronouncing this word, I immediately feel warm in my soul, I remember the wonderful soundtrack and completely immerse myself in my thoughts. Before reviewing, I immediately want to note that this game gave me a new perception of computer games, and gave me a great childhood.

I myself am not an ordinary player in Terraria, and there are few such oldies, because I got acquainted with Terraria even before its release, or more precisely, before the official release of the game on Steam (May 16, 2011). And although I have played 200 hours of this game in my Steam, I actually played it for about 1000 hours. When I was little, I, like all children, played Minecraft, and I really liked this game, I thought that I could not find a better game. But one fine day, my dad came home from work and told me about Terraria, which just appeared. Another employee told Dad about the game, and another employee told this employee, and then I don't know the story of the spread of rumors about a brand new freshly baked Terraria. When I first started the game, I created my character, spending several hours on it, pressed the button to create a world, and found myself on the ground. Someone walked next to me, his name was Guide, who first fell into the abyss ... I don't know why he did it, but it didn't really bother me. The first thing I learned was how to walk, jump and dig, and it was incredibly fun! After that I dug a hole for myself, buried myself on top and went to play Minecraft ... Don't judge strictly, but for a child then Minecraft was much more colorful, and had a 3D view, and not a cropped 3D space along the Z axis. But a couple of days later I went back in into the game, and again continued to explore the world, the game did not cause as much enthusiasm for me as many people who have started playing quite recently. And I don't know if it's good that I started playing such a raw game. But as time went on, I studied the world of Terraria more and more. I got to know cute teardrop-mongers and creatures that were constantly killing me. I realized that I needed a home to live, and that's when I discovered one of the best aspects of not only this game, but one of the best aspects of all the games I've played - building. So I gave up traveling and started BUILDING and DIGGING! And then this game completely sucked me in. I quit Minecraft and started DIGGING, KILLING, AND EXPLORING. I met new residents who can SELL! And a nurse who can CHOOSE! I also realized that the Guide is not a useless piece of garbage, and that you can have a heart-to-heart talk with him. In the end, I killed the ominous Eye of Cthulhu, which sowed fear, and the game ended there ... But soon new updates came out, I downloaded new versions and went all over again. And it was interesting. I went through each update, and did not get a mental pleasure. Since I like everything more difficult, I started playing the game on the Expert Advisor, and later on the Master. But all this was not enough for me! And I started to go through mods, for those who know Calamity mod, I went through this game with Revenge and Death modes, and also after a few hundred attempts I went through Boss Rush. Then I lost my nerves.

With each update, the game brought new emotions and a colorful world to the players and me. Every progress you make is much more satisfying than the last one and continues to push you forward, to the point where you don't stop. There is no point in talking about old versions, so I'll tell you a couple (hundreds) of words about the new Terraria.

For me this game became a home in which I felt comfortable. The game is currently in the game about 500 varieties of mobs. There are also 19 bosses and 13 mini-bosses, as well as 3 additional bosses in the mobile version. And from listing recipes you can break your tongue. Sloped blocks, paints, different walls were added to the game, each block merged together, each block interacted with other blocks. Light sources, different platforms that you may have used. All of this and more meant that anything imaginable could be built. Many people create amazing mechanisms and worlds, better than on paper!) Although they made a convenient interface for creating my character in the game, I also devote a lot of time to creating a character). And the music and style of play makes me crazy. I bought this game for my every account, and made all my friends, no matter if it was voluntary, to purchase this masterpiece. And if you are thinking whether to buy this game, I can hardly answer you ... YES !!! This game is amazing both solo and when playing with friends! You can catch hares and then fill the whole world of your friend with them! It's worth buying for this!

I can confidently say that Terraria has become my corner of safety, this is my home, there is no place easier and quieter than it.

Thanks Andrew Spinks, Whitney Spinks ❤
Thanks Re-Logic ❤
Thanks Terraria ❤
Thanks for reading ❤

23049894.review:
This review applies to Terraria 1.3.0.8 and earlier.

The essence of [i]Terraria[/i] is that it prioritizes fun! It's not a game where players must fear losing progress due to forgetting safety measures or manage breakable tools. The game knows how to bring out a sense of enjoyment and achievement. Grinding is an option, not a requirement or an excuse to drag out game time. Besides, there is much to discover and do in the game. Clocking in at 1,000+ hours, having all 88 achievements, and introducing multiple friends to the game should be indicative of that. With that being said, I'll list some pros/cons I've found memorable.

[b]Pros[/b]
[list]
    [*][b]Customization[/b]: There is a staggering amount of customization available in-game. You not only can choose from several basic character designs but also have a plethora of armors, costumes, accessories, and pets for your character. You can also color/dye any of your equipment and get all sorts of flashy effects. Dyes aren't consumable, so you have few restrictions on perfecting your assemblage.
    [*][b]Exploration[/b]: The [i]Terraria[/i] world may be finite, but it is incredibly diverse. Each biome has its own personality and houses many unique elements. It takes a minimum of three worlds to discover everything, and that's only with absurd luck (see "The Creation of the Guide" painting). The game additionally has an impressive number of flavor. That rubble on the ground can be dug up, and a Worm might pop out from it. You can reignite the burnt-out Campfire in that small cavern. You didn't think that NPCs could fend for themselves during a Blood Moon or invasion, did you? Just when you think you've learned everything about the [i]Terraria[/i] world, you discover something surprising.
    [*][b]Creativity[/b]: [i]Terraria[/i] is as much as about creating your world as it is exploring it. Blocks and furniture are not just for aesthetics, but they also introduce some neat mechanics. Players looking to engineer stuff will enjoy the contraptions possible by the wiring mechanic, and designers will love being able to paint the overworld with a wide spectrum of colors. [i]Terraria[/i] features innovative design at its finest.
    [*][b]Progression options[/b]: Like any good RPG, there's a great sense of progress made in a playthrough. You mine or slay enemies for the materials needed to upgrade equipment, and the world is bountiful enough that this progress never feels linear or constrained. Even the achievements flow nicely, never feeling too easy, cheap, or absurdly difficult.
    You never need to rely crutch items to make progress. Rather, in my experience, my friends and I frequently [i]had too many options[/i] and had to reluctantly store away some of our neat loot. There is always something to switch to if a playstyle becomes easy or repetitive.
    [*][b]Balance[/b]: A game can become boring if there is a certain playstyle players fall into. [i]Terraria[/i] manages to find the right balance so that all playstyles have a fair shot at completing the game. There is no bottleneck or singular Infinity+1 Sword needed for progress.
    [*][b]Diversity[/b]: [i]Terraria[/i] promotes itself as a game for any type of player, and that claim certainly has truth in it. The game has gameplay suited for battlers, explorers, and builders, and I can also tack on several options that appeal to other types of players. Collectors will balk at the quantity of items and achievements offered, and players can challenge themselves to make progress with nearly any conduct. Play with only melee/ranged/magic/summoning weapons? Sure. A yo-yo only run? That's popular! No crafting/mining? Certainly. Play the entire game upside-down? Of course--and that's bug-free! If that's not enough, you can fire up a world in Expert Mode for the extra challenge. There's something for everyone.
    I've had a friend who would ask on his first playthrough 'Can I do ____ in the game?' and I could answer in the positive the majority of the time. Just for starters, you can teleport, build trap-filled dungeons, set up PVP minigames, and record the soundtrack. The game's breadth is incredible.
    [*][b]Automation[/b]: [i]Terraria[/i] would be daunting without any form of automation. You have thousands of items, hundreds of monsters, dozens of mechanics, and an expansive world to build on or dig through. The game offers much to ease the burden of management. Auto-select picks the right tool rather than requiring manual selection. The smart cursor allows for one-click digging. Quick-stacking is much more convenient than depositing items one-by-one, chest-by-chest. Farming is not only feasible but easy. Making measured builds is simplified with items like the Ruler. The game naturally provides the player ease-of-use tools so a playthrough can be focused on the fun stuff rather than on chores.
    [*][b]Performance[/b]: Many games fall off a prospective player's wishlist due to system requirements. [i]Terraria[/i] is a game that features a crazy amount of sprites, particle effects, physics, lighting, and entity interaction. Being a 2-D game only nets you that much speed before optimizations come into play *cough*[i]Starbound[/i]*cough*. The game's requirements are reasonable and the gameplay is optimized such that it doesn't require a bulky system to run on. I was able to run it decently on a 2007 year-old desktop on Windows XP with low-end specifications. The performance of the game to medium- and some low-end systems makes it accessible to a broad demographic of players. On the other hand, if you have a high-end system, go ahead and fire up that Color lighting mode and enjoy [i]Terraria[/i] in its full glory.
    [*][b]Quality of life[/b]: Many games have little quirks that people have to accept to enjoy. Not only is [i]Terraria[/i]'s gameplay mainly devoid of bugs, but it also buffs out these quirks. Players are separated from worlds, allowing for easy singleplayer-to-multiplayer transfer. Characters can ascend blocks without needing to jump. Chests containing items don't explode if you try to harvest them. Keys are easily remappable for those familiar with alternate control schemes. Quick-stacking skips 'favorite' items. You can use the in-game system for taking wide screenshots for giant builds. You can set player configurations to ease the smallest of annoyances. In general, you never feel you're fighting the game's controls and interface.
    [*][b]Continued updates[/b]: It would be very easy for [i]Terraria[/i], as popular as it is, to offer game expansions as paid DLC. The developers, instead, make their continued updates absolutely free to owners of the game. The developer-community relationship is superb.
[/list]

[b]Cons[/b]
[list]
    [*][b]New player friendliness[/b]: The in-game help system is stunted, and players can easily become overwhelmed by the ever-growing number of toys in [i]Terraria[/i]'s sandbox. Many people resort to a guide to help them through the game.
    [*][b]Grinding[/b]: While the game does not require noticeable grinding to progress, several tangents in the game require patience and luck. That fancy teleportation item pretty much necessitates a farm in the Hallow. The last component of a PDA could be hundreds of monster drops or fishing quests away. At a rate of one quest per in-game day, the 200 fishing quests achievement would require 4,800 minutes (3 1/3 days) to complete without resorting to tricks. It can be frustrating to have an achievement be left incomplete as a stretch, yet [i]Terraria[/i] is not above this issue.
    [*][b]Moddability[/b]: [i]Terraria[/i] is extensive enough that it doesn't need additional features, but people have been able to decode the game and develop external software and mods for a better game experience. It would be a boon if the game was open to the modding community for extended gameplay.
[/list]

76984308.review:
[h1] 💻/📱 Description: [/h1]
Terraria is among the BEST if not [b] the best [/b] game of this [b] decade, [/b] which surprises me considering its very low price. The content is beyond overwhelming with many bosses, challenges and options that you won’t ever get bored of. The game revolves around [b] you [/b] the player, as the difficulty and gameplay change depending upon your progression. The art style and music are very exceptional, bringing us the fanbase pleasant memories even to this day.

[h1] 📖 Setting: [/h1]
[h3] Summary [/h3]
Terraria is a land full of mystery and wonder. You the adventure are given the task to cleanse this magical world from the spreading [b] cancer [/b] called Hollow/Corruption. Many powerful beings will stand in your way, so grab some loot, find allies and restore the balance. Since many players forget the fact that Terraria includes a story in the first place. I suggest you read the lore from the [url= https://terraria.gamepedia.com/Lore] Wiki [/url] to get accustomed to the plot.

[h1] 🕹️ Gameplay: [/h1]
Terraria refers to casual and hardcore players alike. You can slay forces or start creating buildings, without though being obliged to do so. The game offers a variety of blocks and items that encourage creativity. You can even build your mini-golf park! The goal here is to have fun and not just constantly grind for loot.

[h3] Difficulty [/h3]
The actual Difficulty mode is a character set selected during character creation. There are 5 types of difficulty: Softcore, Mediumcore, Hardcore and the newly added [b] Journey [/b] mode that can only be played on journey worlds. All the above-mentioned modes change the penalty upon death.

[table]
[tr]
[th] Description[/th]
[th] Difficulty [/th]
[/tr]
[tr]
[td] Characters start with extra equipment [/td]
[td] Journey [/td] 
[/tr] 
[tr] 
[td] Characters drop [b] coins [/b] upon death [/td] 
[td] Classic [/td] 
[/tr] 
[tr] 
[td] Characters drop [b] items [/b] on death [/td] 
[td] Mediumcore [/td] 
[/tr]
[tr] 
[td] Characters cannot [b] respawn!! [/b]  [/td] 
[td] Hardcore [/td] 
[/tr] 
[/table]

Another form of difficulty is [b] world modes. [/b] Those are separate settings that apply to the [b] world, [/b] rather than the [b] character. [/b] Players may choose between Journey, Classic, Expert, and Master mode when creating a new seed. Each mode provides more loot, as well as special accessories depending on the difficulty you have chosen. I advise [b] new [/b] players to start with the Classic mode, as Expert and Master are very demanding for a novice adventurer.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2894347971
[h3] Starting your adventure [/h3]
Terraria starts its gameplay slow and steady, as it should be. You begin your journey with only 3 tools (sword, axe, pickaxe) at your disposal and a companion useful for his crafting guides. It’s up to [b] you [/b] the player whether you want to challenge the game since your imagination, skill and creativity shape the word and thus the adventure. As a tip, I suggest you start building a small house in the beginning.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2894343444
[h3] Interactive playstyle [/h3]
Terraria forces [b] you [/b] the player to manipulate the environment to survive. You can chop trees used for crafting; mine rocks used for building or combine all the materials to cross large gaps etc. Physics plays a major role in the game’s playstyle, so do expect lots of deaths caused by [b] fall damage. [/b] There is also a small detail concerning nightfall, but that’s a surprise for you to explore.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2894342641
[h3] Scaling [/h3]
[b] Grinding [/b]
Terraria is very famous for its grinding potential. There are many repeatable bosses, each offering different and unique [b] treasure bags [/b] that are considered valuable for your future encounters. Countless items offered by a specific boss or gained by certain activities, such as fishing, have a very low [b] drop percentage [/b]. This concept favours repeatability, so do be patient, as sometimes even the best things in life take a while.

[b] Classes [/b]
There are 4 classes in Terraria: Magic, Ranged, Melee and Summoning. Each class requires different armour sets and weapons that provide unique stats and abilities, depending upon the material they were made from. It is most favourable to stick with 1 class during a playthrough, as this way you can aim your focus on specific items and equipment. Read the [url= https://terraria.gamepedia.com/Guide:Class_setups]Wiki [/url] and choose carefully which role to main first.

[b] Loot [/b]
There are lots of accessories, mounts as well as vanity items with interesting [b] specialities [/b] that bring joy to competitive and creative players alike. A perfect example is the [b] Cloud in a Bottle [/b] which grants the user the ability to extra-jump midair. You can combine the accessories to create even stronger ones in the Tinkerer's Workshop. There are countless combinations, so take your time while reading the [url= https://terraria.gamepedia.com/Tinkerer%27s_Workshop]Wiki. [/url] 

[h3] Wiki, Wiki and more Wiki [/h3]
Overall, the experience is amazing, however, the learning curve is extremely demanding. This is a feature that does not go well with many players. As you have noticed above, you [b] will [/b] have to consult the [b] wiki [/b] regularly to truly master the game. Otherwise, you going to encounter many problems and difficulties that eventually will lead to confusion. Terraria is [b] very [/b] grind demanding game, so bring some friends in your journeys as co-op is more than encouraging!

[h1] 👁‍🗨 Visuals: [/h1]
Terraria runs pretty well even on a [b] potato [/b] Pc. It is a small game with a gorgeous yet simple artstyle that continues to captivate me to this day. The game runs smoothly in low settings with minor loading times. In the rare case you encounter problems with performance, I suggest you turn off the effects.

[h1] 🎧 Audio: [/h1]
Terraria’s music is [b] exceptional [/b] in its way. Every biome, boss as well as event has its unique song that fits the theme. 16212660.review:
This Indie sandbox game really has a little something for everyone.
Whether you are into building, creating pixel art, PvP, PvE, this game has something for you!

Once you've made your character, you start off in the world of Terraria. Your first goal is survival. During the first day, you deal with pesky slimes while you gather the materials needed to build a shelter before nightfall. Once night comes, the undead swarm you. Are you resting safely in your new house, or are you forced to fight until daybreak?

If you thought slimes and undead were all you had to worry about in this world, you were wrong. Outlandish minions and deadly bosses await every turn, as you explore the many different environments in the world. Defeating them will reward you with new materials, weapons, armor, and even trophies to display.

Beware of the corruption, an environment native to Terraria, that slowly spreads, trying to shroud your world in darkness. Or, will your world contain the crimson? A festering landscape, oozing with blood and flesh that constantly tries to devour you. You will not be left defenceless against these horrors, however! You can work to purify the land to its original state.

In your travels, you will find resources that you can mine and gather. Combine them into powerful weapons and armor, or shape them into building blocks for new structures. As you grow and progress, NPCs will begin to flock to your buildings, offering you aid. You will even find some out in the world, waiting to be rescued.

Tunnel through the earth, or take wing and fly to the clouds. Purify or corrupt. Build or destroy. The world of Terraria is yours to explore, and mold into your image.

96828528.review: 800h+ of gameplay for $5, still in love with this game after ~6 years

154406040.review:
... should probably write a review for this game at some point.

Here's how I'd summarize Terraria:
[list]
[*]Your goal is to make a super powerful character that destroys all the boss monsters.
[*]And then you destroy those boss monsters.
[*]Along the way, you go exploring, mining, build some 2D houses, explore *a* dungeon or two, farm a bunch of mob loot...
[*]Oh, and just for fun, there's also fishing, golfing, logic circuits, dress-up, a thousand decorative items for building, ...
[/list]

When getting new people into this game, I noted these common issues:
[list]
[*]You rarely know what to do next. The onboarding *exists*, the hints are *there*, but it's not enough to replace a wiki.
[*]While the spritework is nice, the small scale of everything holds it back. Various details in tiles and character cosmetics are too small to really appreciate, which can make the look of the game unappealing to some people. (Though if you're already looking at this review, you probably won't mind that as much.)
[*]The game's "two phases" appeal to different people. Early game is slow, with slow exploration, awkward attacks, and a bunch of "hold left click for 10 minutes" moments. Late game is fast-paced, challenging, and almost rushes by. If you're ONLY into one of these two, you may have trouble dealing with the other.
[*]The small scale, coupled with the fast pace of combat in the lategame, lead to some visibility problems. Aiming at enemies that are off-screen is a somewhat common occurrence in this game.
[/list]

My recommendation for your first playthrough:
[list]
[*]Play with friends, preferably someone who already knows how this game works.
[*]When making a character, choose "Classic" ("drop coins on death"). "Mediumcore" is a big deal, so don't choose that unless you know what you're in for.
[*]When making a world, *try* Expert mode, *especially* when playing multiplayer. A lot of the more interesting mechanics are only available there.
[*]If you're playing solo (or nobody in your group knows what to do), talk to the Guide NPC a LOT, or use a wiki.
[*]Start by exploring and making basic houses, continue by battling a few bosses, THEN get into building fancier things. (You gain a lot of building/mining abilities at that point.)
[*]Anytime you find a new item that has "Material" written in its description, show it to the Guide NPC to learn what it's for.
[*]Dropping the doll in the lava will have serious consequences.
[/list]

This game's great. Not for everyone, but I still get obsessed with it every now and then.
One should not wish for sequels, but if this game ever got one, I'd have high hopes for it.
The mods are also great. Lots of cool content to explore there, if you're ever craving for more.
Give it a try. It's dirt cheap for what it is.

92116097.review:
Wow... 10 years...
I wasn't the first Terrarian by a long shot, but my mother was among the ones in Beta/Alpha (I don't remember which one, I just know it was beginning stages). She played it, fell in love with its charm, and knew I would enjoy it as well, so a few months after its full release, she bought it for me as a gift. I fell in love, just as she did, the charm of the visuals, simplicity of the game play, the music that gives me nostalgia each time I hear it (especially the daytime track, those beeps and boops are forever ingrained in my head). I played for hours and hours just fiddling around, digging, exploring, creating more worlds to explore and dig into just for the fun of it. I played to the point I FAR surpassed my mother in Terraria knowledge, and she often asked me for help XD. I watched from the sidelines (as I was/am too shy to really go into the community) as the game grew, changed, and developed into what it is now. While I honestly do not play as much as I used to, I mostly played after big updates to play around and explore with the new content, I still hold those memories fondly, and I'm pretty sure I still have my first world out in my files somewhere.

But that's enough story time, you came for my review:
I can't recommend this game enough to ANYONE who has any interest in the genre, the pixel graphics are incredibly charming and cute, the controls might take a small amount of getting used to for some people unfamiliar with it, but they're not hard. The content is vast, you almost NEED to go into the wiki pages if you want to see it all. You can easily sink hours into the game if you're not careful, and literally explore worlds upon worlds of some fascinating procedurally generated landscapes and tunnels. The price of the game is definitely worth the amount of content you get.

If there was anything I can think of (at this moment) that could be a downside, it might be that it could be a bit too easy to not know what to do, especially if you are playing on your own at first, and have no idea what you are supposed to do, there is a Guide NPC, but he doesn't exactly convey much about what needs to be done.
Yet at the same time, that's part of the point, this game is about freedom, to do whatever you want in whatever way you want to do it.

Happy 10 years, Terraria <3

70407246.review:
[h1]Terraria is a game I recommend everyone to own on Steam.   It consistantly goes on sale for $2.50, and this game offers dozens of hours of solid entertainment. [/h1]

To be completely honest, for years I did not like Terraria. The biggest problem with the game is you literally don't know what to do or how to progress in the game without looking up a guide on the Terraria Wiki, or by asking more experienced players. To me, I just find that as bad game design.  There could have been some sort of quest log that gave you some indication of what to do next, otherwise the beginning of the game becomes rather dull.

Moving on, once you do know what you are doing, the game becomes surprisingly more enjoyable as Terraria focuses on combat and boss encounters. Each boss is different from one another, and are actually challenging. The game limits you from getting better gear until a specific boss is defeated which keeps the challenge high throughout.

Apart from that, as you kill bosses new enemies and events will appear in the game unlocking a vast new variety of weapons, items, and equipment. 

One thing I had not realized is the incredible amount of content Terraria offers. As soon as you think you are done with the game, it just keeps going with even more bosses, more grind for even better gear, and just so much new stuff as you go along. (be sure to keep checking the wiki to see what bosses are next and how to unlock them)


[b]It is very important that you play this game with a friend. Playing it solo is simply not as fun, especially considering the time investment.[/b]


General overview:
+ Loads of content
+ Fun combat system with a large variety of weapons, spells, and gear.
+ Lots of fantastic bosses
+ Very challenging
+ An ever-changing world with loads to explore
+ Great fun with friends
+ Very easy to host a server and game is very minimal on resources (meaning anyone with a PC can enjoy this, even on a laptop)

- Somewhat impossible to progress without a guide
- The first half of the game is rather boring compared to the later half
- A bit straining on the eyes with pixel graphics, especially with a high resolution monitor
- A bit too challenging at times (especially playing solo)
- Resources are limited, meaning you won't be able to get items without generating a new world (your character can move between worlds and servers)  [b]Highly recommend generating a medium to large world[/b]


To sum things up, Terraria is a fantastic game to play with at least one friend (preferably just 2-4 ). It offers an extremely high amount of content, lots of bosses, fun gameplay, lots to explore and craft, and its cheap! 

+++ Highly recommend.

50325234.review:
Let's start the review with the obvious: go buy this game. 
Now, let's get to the review:
Everybody (that doesn't play Terraria) says that this game is 2D Minecraft. Well, they're wrong. Terraria is like Minecraft but better in any way.
Exploring feels like it should be: quick, simple and rewarding and the arsenal of tools like pickaxes, drills, ropes and torches makes that even more enjoyable. The environment is full of chests and vases that reward you just for walking around. You can also found Heart Crystals that boost your Max HP and Fallen Stars that boost your Max Mana.
Combat feels clumsy at the beggining, but the more you play, the better it will get. The combat turns from a Copper Sword Stabby-Stab to Missiles, Bursts of Energy, Homing Bullets, Falling Meteorites, Massive Swords.
Mining is as it should be: quick! You can spend only 5min just mining a rare ore, where in Minecraft, you will spend hours to find Diamonds and it depends on layers, stripminings, caverns, etc. In Terraria, you have things to help you find ore more easily, such as better tools, Pets that give you light, torches that highlight treasures, potions that show you where the treasures is, equipables that describe your surroundings, bombs/tnt that, for sure, help you get rid of the terrain and you don't feel that you've wasted your materials spending them.
The Progression in this game is top notch. In the beggining you can't even beat a blob, but as soon as you grab some armor you can beat it easily. It's fun to discover that you're still too weak to walk to other biomes like the desert and jungle. And after you get comfortable with the gameplay, when you can beat every mob in the world, the game has the BALLS to strip that liberty away and put you in Noob Phase again. The switch between Pre-Hardmode and Hardmode is a huge step for gaming. It strips your sense of greatness without striping you off your items.
The world, your map change with the flow of the game, new ores appear, the ore changes between worlds, so it is never the same, new mobs appear, corrupted biomes spread to other biomes, and if you don't pay attention, it will, eventually, take over the whole map.
Even if you had explored the map previously, you will still explore the same areas because new ore, loot and enemies will appear. It never gets old being killed by Unicorns and Pixie Fairies. 
This is the first game where I do like brewing my potions, in Minecraft that function feels useless, either you don't use it at all, or you only use it for boss fights or breathing underwater. In Terraria you use them for everything. You use potions for Scaveging, Danger Hunting, Boss Fighting, Teleporting, Flying, Water Walking... It feels good using potions, and you don't feel cheated when you use them.
Fishing is under appreciated. This mechanic is way better than Minecraft's or Stardew Valley's. You are not obligated to do it, but it will reward you with ore, vanity items, furniture, money, very good equipables, rods, bait, fish (that can be used for potions). It can be boring at times, but you don't even have to be alert, it functions with a simple mouse click.
Building is god-like, you can build everything, you have all kinds of furniture, you can mold blocks with your hammer, and you can even paint all blocks in the game or create your custom biomes with paint. Even if you are bad at building and you'd like to build great things (like me) you can easily copy any screenshot of any building you see browsing the web. The houses you building will all feel comfortable.
Wiring is like Minecraft's Redstone, but more simpler (sometimes). Wiring gives you the opportunity to build traps, build farms and teleport yourself around the map (yes, TELEPORT). Wiring also gives you motives to be careful when exploring caves because there might be traps lurking.
Even if you play alone, your world feels alive, everywhere you go you have something. Wanna go left/right? You have Desert, Tundra, Jungle, Beaches, Meteorite, Hallow, Corruption/Crimson. Wanna go up? You have Sky Islands and Sky Lakes.
Wanna go down? You have Granite, Marble, Spider-Nests, Mushroom Biomes, and even Hell (Underworld).
The world isn't infinite like in Minecraft (I know it isn't infinite, but c'mon) but it still feels huge, and it even will change overtime with your adventure.
Terraria will still offer you options like Pets, Light Pets, Mounts, Minecarts, Grappling Hooks and even Wings that you can collect if you feel like getting all the items.
Even with all of this variety Terraria will offer events like Blood Moon, Solar Eclipse, etc which will give you another look at more new mobs, even more loot and even more fun. Some of the events change over time too, and offer great loot.
And the bosses? Omg, the bosses are amazing. When you play, you're always thinking of when the new one's gonna come out. You'll get addicted to beat bosses, and Terraria has a fair share of bosses. In the beggining they feels kinda weak and easy, but it will change over time too. Bosses have themes behind them, Queen Bee is in the Jungle, Eater of Worlds is in the Corruption, Moon Lord appears after you defeat the Lunar Events, etc.
Ah, and it even has multiple classes, and each and every one of them feels rewarding to play. Every one of them is fun to play, and the game doesn't force you to choose one of them at the beggining of the game, giving you time to experiment each class during your playtime.
NPC's, in Terraria are very good and distinguished from each other. They don't look alike and don't "NAH" "OH" around. Each have their own personality and each one of them serves a purpose and gives life to your world, you will never feel alone.
After all of this, you get another difficulty, which increases the difficulty (ofc), but increases the drop quality and it even gives you Expert only items that are worth the difficulty just for the items alone.
The game feels rewarding and delivers in everything that is shown, and it is still being updated.
This game is not grindy, you will only have to grind for specific items that are not required.
And even with all of that, you still have mods. I have not experienced them, but everybody , in the Terraria community, knows that mods are god like. Mods like Calamity and Thorium are a must.
And the Soundtrack is very good. Each biome has it's own theme, and it's very recognizable. You can tell the day/night cycle just by listening, or the biome you're in and the transitions between biomes are very well made. The bosses have their own themes too, but I'm always too busy fighting them so I don't even have the chance to listen.
I've played so many games and I have NEVER seen a community like Terraria's. Everyone is so helpful, and the Youtubers are so memorable, from Happydays to Python and Grobeman.
So, after reading my review, and looking at the "Overwhelmingly Positive" reviews for this game, what's your excuse for not buying? It's the best time to buy this game, it will get another update soon full with new stuff. This game is still relevant, God dammit
Seriously, why don't my friends like this game?!
